I'm not saying capital markets are the goal, or need to be everyone's focus!\n\nI am saying being oblivious to them or thinking any startup or fund is not a direct participant is naive.

There are two types of people in Silicon Valley: 

1. People who understand they're a part of capital markets.

2. People who want to raise capital, have stock options, have liquidity events ‚Äî but don't understand that this means they're a part of capital markets.

I find it poetic that there is so much diversity in the makeup of SFs trees, that they were the result of deliberate initiative of the community, that most are not from here but rather came from elsewhere, & that resilience is one of the main selection criteria.

There were no trees on streets until around 1960. Planting on streets was city-run from the 60s until 1981 when it lost funding. It then transitioned to being carried out by volunteers, principally @SFUrbanForester.

SF had almost no trees in the late 1800s. When Golden Gate Park was formed in 1870, the landscaper of Central Park advised it would be a mistake to plant trees in SF ‚Äî the windy, sandy soil, lack of rain, fog and dryness would be inhospitable. Today SF has almost 200,000 trees.

For anyone curious about trees of San Francisco, here‚Äôs a list of the top 20 most planted. 

1981-2002: Purple-Leaf Plum
2003-2013: Strawberry Tree

3/ This will increase pressure amongst foreign nationals in the US to get a masters degree to some extent. I'm not sure that's a good thing. I'd rather see the # of H1Bs increased. \n\nIt's a privilege that talented people ‚Äîthat US cos want to hire‚Äî want to move their lives here.

2/ Background for those who don't have it, H1Bs are allocated in a 2 part lottery. Round 1: 20,000 spots given to applicants with >masters degree. Round 2: 65,000 spots given to remaining masters + everyone else. \n\nThis rule change flips the order, increasing the odds for masters

1/ Noteworthy though incremental change to USCIS H1B rules this week. https://t.co/DyK9S3Onh7

TLDR:
1. Odds for >masters degree should go from 51% to 55%, & bachelors 38% to 31% (est. & based on 2018 #s). Same # of H1Bs, lottery order flipped.
2. Less paperwork if not accepted.
